Pelagic Fish-eating Predators: Large predatory fish such as tunas and billfishes that occupy high trophic levels in the open ocean, contributing to energy transfer and regulation of prey populations.

Reef Fish-eating Predators: Medium to large predatory fish that inhabit coral reefs, controlling prey fish populations and maintaining reef health.

Demersal Fish-eating Predators: Bottom-dwelling predatory fish, including dogfishes, that control populations of fishes and invertebrates on and near the seafloor.

Reef Invertebrate Predators: Includes reef sharks, skates, rays, and large predatory invertebrates such as octopus and sea anemones, controlling populations of reef-dwelling organisms.

Pelagic Invertebrate Predators: Includes cephalopods and jellyfish, important predators in open ocean ecosystems, particularly on zooplankton.

Benthic Invertebrate Predators: Includes starfish, sea urchins, and benthic carnivorous zooplankton, controlling populations of benthic invertebrates.

Reef Herbivores: Herbivorous fish and sea turtles that control algal growth and maintain reef health.

Pelagic Herbivores: Includes fish such as flying fish and mesopelagic fish that feed on plankton, contributing to energy transfer and regulation of plankton populations.

Benthic Herbivores: Includes sea urchins, sea cucumbers, and benthic grazers, controlling algal growth and affecting benthic community structure.

Reef Corals: Reef-building colonial animals that create complex habitat structure through calcium carbonate deposition, providing shelter and habitat for a variety of organisms.

Soft Corals and Sea Anemones: Colonial animals that contribute to reef habitat complexity without building calcium carbonate structures, providing shelter and habitat for a variety of organisms.

Pelagic Bacteria and Phytoplankton: Includes diatoms, dinoflagellates, nanoplankton, picoplankton, and pelagic bacteria, forming the base of the marine food web and contributing to nutrient cycling.

Benthic Bacteria and Microalgae: Includes sedimentary bacteria, meiobenthos, benthic filter feeders, and microalgae, forming the base of the benthic food web and contributing to nutrient cycling.

Zooplankton: Includes mesozooplankton, microzooplankton, and large carnivorous zooplankton, serving as food for larger animals and contributing to energy transfer.

Seagrass, Mangroves, and Salt Marsh Plan: Marine and coastal vegetation that form important habitats and nursery areas, contributing to nutrient cycling and shoreline protection.

Mesopelagic Benthivores: Small to mid-sized fish that feed on benthic organisms and live in the mesopelagic zone, contributing to energy transfer and regulation of benthic populations.

Deep-sea Benthivores: Small to mid-sized fish that feed on benthic organisms and live on the shelf or seamounts, contributing to energy transfer and regulation of benthic populations.

Deep-sea Demersal Fish: Medium to large demersal fish that live in slope or seamount waters, contributing to energy transfer and regulation of demersal populations.

Pelagic Sharks: Open-ocean predators that help regulate populations of fishes and squids, occupying high trophic levels.

Discards and Detritus: Carrion, freshly discarded material from fisheries activities, and detritus, serving as food for scavengers and decomposers, contributing to nutrient cycling.
